paragraphs.text:
%md
### Introduction

In this lab you will use Spark SQL via DataFrames API in Part 1 of the lab and SQL in Part 2 of the lab to explore an Airline Dataset. This is a very interesting dataset that is further explored in other demo notebooks.

msg.data:
Introduction

In this lab you will use Spark SQL via DataFrames API in Part 1 of the lab and SQL in Part 2 of the lab to explore an Airline Dataset. This is a very interesting dataset that is further explored in other demo notebooks.

result.msg:
Introduction

In this lab you will use Spark SQL via DataFrames API in Part 1 of the lab and SQL in Part 2 of the lab to explore an Airline Dataset. This is a very interesting dataset that is further explored in other demo notebooks.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Concepts

A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns. 
#
It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. 
#
DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. 
#
**[See SparkSQL docs for more info](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html#dataframes)**

msg.data:
Concepts

A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns.

It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood.

DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs.

See SparkSQL docs for more info

If you would like to **learn more about Scala**, here's an excellent **[Beginner Scala Tutorial](http://www.dhgarrette.com/nlpclass/scala/basics.html)**.

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the next paragraph we are going to download datasets using shell commands. A shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can can be invoked by 
prepending a block of shell commands with a line containing `%sh` characters.

msg.data:
In the next paragraph we are going to download datasets using shell commands. A shell command in a Zeppelin notebook can can be invoked by
prepending a block of shell commands with a line containing %sh characters.

result.msg:

paragraphs.title: Download Datasets
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# You will now download a subset of 2008 flights (only 100k lines)
# The full dataset may be found here: http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/the-data.html

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roberthryniewicz/datasets/master/airline-dataset/flights/flights.csv -O /tmp/flights.csv
echo "Downloaded!"

msg.data: Downloaded!

result.msg: Downloaded!

paragraphs.title: Move Datasets to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# remove existing copies of dataset from HDFS
hadoop fs -rm -r -f /tmp/airflightsdelays

# create directory on HDFS
hadoop fs -mkdir /tmp/airflightsdelays

# put data into HDFS
hadoop fs -put /tmp/flights.csv /tmp/airflightsdelays/

paragraphs.title: Preview Downloaded File
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hadoop fs -cat /tmp/airflightsdelays/flights.csv | head

paragraphs.title: Dataset Description
paragraphs.text:
%angular
Name Description
1 Year 1987-2008
2 Month 1-12
3 DayofMonth 1-31
4 DayOfWeek 1 (Monday) - 7 (Sunday)
5 DepTime actual departure time (local, hhmm)
6 CRSDepTime scheduled departure time (local, hhmm)
7 ArrTime actual arrival time (local, hhmm)
8 CRSArrTime scheduled arrival time (local, hhmm)
9 UniqueCarrier unique carrier code
10 FlightNum flight number
11 TailNum plane tail number
12 ActualElapsedTime in minutes
13 CRSElapsedTime in minutes
14 AirTime in minutes
15 ArrDelay arrival delay, in minutes
16 DepDelay departure delay, in minutes
17 Origin origin IATA airport code
18 Dest destination IATA airport code
19 Distance in miles
20 TaxiIn taxi in time, in minutes
21 TaxiOut taxi out time in minutes
22 Cancelled was the flight cancelled?
23 CancellationCode reason for cancellation (A = carrier, B = weather, C = NAS, D = security)
24 Diverted 1 = yes, 0 = no
25 CarrierDelay in minutes
26 WeatherDelay in minutes
27 NASDelay in minutes
28 SecurityDelay in minutes
29 LateAircraftDelay in minutes

paragraphs.title: Part 1: Using DataFrames to Analyze Dataset

paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
// Create a DataFrame containing Flights with delayed Departure by more than 15 min using "filter"
val delayedDF = df.select("UniqueCarrier", "DepDelay").filter($"DepDelay" > 15).cache
delayedDF.show

msg.data: Total Number of Delayed Flights: 19587

paragraphs.title: Define a UDF to Determine Delays

msg.data:
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.udf
isDelayedUDF: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,IntegerType,List(StringType))

result.msg:
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.udf
isDelayedUDF: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,IntegerType,List(StringType))

paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
// Define a new DataFrame that contains a subset of the original columns and a new column "IsDelayed" by applying a UDF
// isDelayed()  on "DepDelay" column

val updatedDF = df.select($"Year", $"Month", $"DayofMonth", $"DayOfWeek", $"CRSDepTime", $"UniqueCarrier", $"FlightNum", 
                    $"DepDelay", $"Origin", $"Dest", $"TaxiIn", $"TaxiOut", $"Distance",
                    isDelayedUDF($"DepDelay").alias("IsDelayed")).cache

updatedDF.show // Notice new column "IsDelayed"

paragraphs.title: Calculate Percentage of Delayed Flights
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
updatedDF.agg((sum("IsDelayed") * 100 / count("DepDelay")).alias("Percentage of Delayed Flights")).show

Find Avg Taxi-in

paragraphs.title: Compare Total Number of Delayed Flights by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SELECT UniqueCarrier, SUM(isDelayedUDF(DepDelay)) AS NumDelays FROM flightsTempTbl GROUP BY UniqueCarrier

WN	18573
XE	1014

paragraphs.title: Compare Total Delayed Time (min) by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SELECT UniqueCarrier, SUM(DepDelay) AS TotalTimeDelay FROM flightsTempTbl GROUP BY UniqueCarrier

paragraphs.title: Find Average Distance Travelled by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

-- Find average distance by UniqueCarrier from flightsTempTbl
-- order descending by average distance

SELECT UniqueCarrier, avg(Distance) AS AvgDistanceTraveled FROM flightsTempTbl GROUP BY UniqueCarrier ORDER BY AvgDistanceTraveled DESC

XE	738.0677880571909
WN	623.7926638668864

XE	738.0677880571909
WN	623.7926638668864

paragraphs.title: Find Out When Most Flights Get Delayed by Day of Week
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SELECT DayOfWeek, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END AS Delay, COUNT(1) AS Count
FROM flightsTempTbl
GROUP BY DayOfWeek, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END
ORDER BY DayOfWeek

paragraphs.title: Find Out When Most Flights Get Delayed by Hour
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SELECT CAST(CRSDepTime / 100 AS INT) AS Hour, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END AS Delay, COUNT(1) AS Count
FROM flightsTempTbl
GROUP BY CAST(CRSDepTime / 100 AS INT), CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END
ORDER BY Hour

paragraphs.text:
%angular

Save Modes

Save operations can optionally take a SaveMode, that specifies how to handle existing data if present. It is important to realize that these save modes do not utilize any locking and are not atomic. Additionally, when performing a Overwrite, the data will be deleted before writing out the new data.

Mode (Scala/Java) Meaning
SaveMode.ErrorIfExists (default) When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, an exception is expected to be thrown.
SaveMode.Append When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, contents of the DataFrame are expected to be appended to existing data.
SaveMode.Overwrite Overwrite mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, existing data is expected to be overwritten by the contents of the DataFrame.
SaveMode.Ignore Ignore mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, the save operation is expected to not save the contents of the DataFrame and to not change the existing data. This is similar to a CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in SQL.

msg.data:
Save Modes

Save operations can optionally take a SaveMode, that specifies how to handle existing data if present. It is important to realize that these save modes do not utilize any locking and are not atomic. Additionally, when performing a Overwrite, the data will be deleted before writing out the new data.

Mode (Scala/Java) Meaning
SaveMode.ErrorIfExists (default) When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, an exception is expected to be thrown.
SaveMode.Append When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, contents of the DataFrame are expected to be appended to existing data.
SaveMode.Overwrite Overwrite mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, existing data is expected to be overwritten by the contents of the DataFrame.
SaveMode.Ignore Ignore mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, the save operation is expected to not save the contents of the DataFrame and to not change the existing data. This is similar to a CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in SQL.

result.msg:
Save Modes

Save operations can optionally take a SaveMode, that specifies how to handle existing data if present. It is important to realize that these save modes do not utilize any locking and are not atomic. Additionally, when performing a Overwrite, the data will be deleted before writing out the new data.

Mode (Scala/Java) Meaning
SaveMode.ErrorIfExists (default) When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, an exception is expected to be thrown.
SaveMode.Append When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, contents of the DataFrame are expected to be appended to existing data.
SaveMode.Overwrite Overwrite mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, existing data is expected to be overwritten by the contents of the DataFrame.
SaveMode.Ignore Ignore mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, the save operation is expected to not save the contents of the DataFrame and to not change the existing data. This is similar to a CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in SQL.

paragraphs.title: Save to ORC file
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode

// Save and Overwrite results to an ORC file
updatedDF.write.format("orc").mode(SaveMode.Overwrite).save("flightsAndDelays.orc")

msg.data: import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode

result.msg: import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode

paragraphs.title: Load from ORC file
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
// Load results back from ORC file
val dfTest = sqlContext.read.format("orc").load("flightsAndDelays.orc")
dfTest.show

paragraphs.title: Compare DataFrame Sizes (i.e. Compare Original DataFrame with one Loaded from HDFS)

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Saving to Persistent Tables Unlike the `registerTempTable` command, `saveAsTable` will materialize the contents of the dataframe and create a pointer to the data in the HiveMetastore. Persistent tables will still exist even after your Spark program has restarted, as long as you maintain your connection to the same metastore. A DataFrame for a persistent table can be created by calling the `table` method on a `SQLContext` with the name of the table.
By default `saveAsTable` will create a managed table, meaning that the location of the data will be controlled by the metastore. Managed tables will also have their data deleted automatically when a table is dropped.

msg.data:
Saving to Persistent Tables

Unlike the registerTempTable command, saveAsTable will materialize the contents of the dataframe and create a pointer to the data in the HiveMetastore. Persistent tables will still exist even after your Spark program has restarted, as long as you maintain your connection to the same metastore. A DataFrame for a persistent table can be created by calling the table method on a SQLContext with the name of the table.

By default saveAsTable will create a managed table, meaning that the location of the data will be controlled by the metastore. Managed tables will also have their data deleted automatically when a table is dropped.

result.msg:
Saving to Persistent Tables

Unlike the registerTempTable command, saveAsTable will materialize the contents of the dataframe and create a pointer to the data in the HiveMetastore. Persistent tables will still exist even after your Spark program has restarted, as long as you maintain your connection to the same metastore. A DataFrame for a persistent table can be created by calling the table method on a SQLContext with the name of the table.

By default saveAsTable will create a managed table, meaning that the location of the data will be controlled by the metastore. Managed tables will also have their data deleted automatically when a table is dropped.

paragraphs.title: Save to a Table
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
updatedDF.write.format("orc").mode(SaveMode.Overwrite).saveAsTable("flightsPermTbl")

paragraphs.title: Read from Table to a New DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
val dfFromTbl = sqlContext.table("flightsPermTbl")

msg.data: dfFromTbl: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [Year: int, Month: int, DayofMonth: int, DayOfWeek: int, CRSDepTime: int, UniqueCarrier: string, FlightNum: int, DepDelay: string, Origin: string, Dest: string, TaxiIn: string, TaxiOut: string, Distance: int, IsDelayed: int]

result.msg: dfFromTbl: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [Year: int, Month: int, DayofMonth: int, DayOfWeek: int, CRSDepTime: int, UniqueCarrier: string, FlightNum: int, DepDelay: string, Origin: string, Dest: string, TaxiIn: string, TaxiOut: string, Distance: int, IsDelayed: int]

paragraphs.title: Show Elements of DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%spark.spark
dfFromTbl.show(5)

paragraphs.title: Show Tables
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SHOW Tables

-- Notice that unlike flightsTempTbl, flightsPermTbl is a permanent table

msg.data:
tableName	isTemporary
flightstemptbl	true
flightspermtbl	false
sample_07	false
sample_08	false

result.msg:
tableName	isTemporary
flightstemptbl	true
flightspermtbl	false
sample_07	false
sample_08	false

paragraphs.title: Drop Managed Table
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

DROP TABLE flightsPermTbl

paragraphs.title: Describe Table
paragraphs.text:
%spark.sql

SHOW tables
-- notice that flightsPermTbl is no longer available

msg.data:
tableName	isTemporary
flightstemptbl	true
sample_07	false
sample_08	false

result.msg:
tableName	isTemporary
flightstemptbl	true
sample_07	false
sample_08	false
